articles.headline: The Fed’s Vice Chair for Supervision Suggests Big-Bank Regulation Changes
articles.snippet: In a series of changes that has bank lobbyists on the defensive, Michael Barr is calling for higher bank capital and tougher annual stress tests.
articles.abstract: In a series of changes that has bank lobbyists on the defensive, Michael Barr is calling for higher bank capital and tougher annual stress tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael S. Barr, the Federal Reserve’s vice chair for supervision, announced on Monday that he would be pushing for significant changes to how America’s largest banks were overseen in a bid to make them more resilient in times of trouble — partly by ratcheting up how much capital they have to get them through a rough patch.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Emily Flitter and Rob Copeland

articles.headline: Amazon Union Dissidents, in Challenge to Leader, Move to Force Vote
articles.snippet: A split over the stewardship of the union’s high-profile president, Christian Smalls, has led a rival faction to file a lawsuit seeking an election.
articles.abstract: A split over the stewardship of the union’s high-profile president, Christian Smalls, has led a rival faction to file a lawsuit seeking an election.
articles.lead_paragraph: A dissident group within the Amazon Labor Union, the only certified union in the country representing Amazon employees, filed a complaint in federal court Monday seeking to force the union to hold a leadership election.

articles.headline: Putin Met With Mercenary Leaders He Had Called Traitors During Mutiny
articles.snippet: The Kremlin’s disclosure of the meeting with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin and other Wagner group commanders hinted at the power they wield, but left many questions unanswered.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin’s disclosure of the meeting with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin and other Wagner group commanders hinted at the power they wield, but left many questions unanswered.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia held a lengthy meeting with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin and commanders of his Wagner private military company just days after they had launched a mutiny that put the nation on the brink of a civil conflict, the Kremlin disclosed on Monday.

articles.headline: Biden Bets High-Level Diplomacy Can Cool Fiery Relations With China
articles.snippet: President Biden hopes the diplomatic trips this summer by his aides lead to frank talks with Xi Jinping and other Chinese officials before the 2024 U.S. elections.
articles.abstract: President Biden hopes the diplomatic trips this summer by his aides lead to frank talks with Xi Jinping and other Chinese officials before the 2024 U.S. elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: After three years of self-isolation by China, President Biden’s top aides are flying into Beijing throughout the summer to try to convince and cajole Chinese officials, including Xi Jinping, the nation’s leader, on building a new foundation for relations.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Keith Bradsher and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: U.S. Students’ Progress Stagnated Last School Year, Study Finds
articles.snippet: Despite billions in federal aid, students are not making up ground in reading and math: “We are actually seeing evidence of backsliding.”
articles.abstract: Despite billions in federal aid, students are not making up ground in reading and math: “We are actually seeing evidence of backsliding.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite billions of federal dollars spent to help make up for pandemic-related learning loss, progress in reading and math stalled over the past school year for elementary and middle-school students, according to a new national study released on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Blocked Rail Crossings Snarl Towns, but Congress Won’t Act
articles.snippet: The industry has used its muscle to prevent federal, state and local governments from penalizing companies that park freight trains across roads for hours or days.
articles.abstract: The industry has used its muscle to prevent federal, state and local governments from penalizing companies that park freight trains across roads for hours or days.
articles.lead_paragraph: Freight trains frequently stop and block the roads of York, Ala., sometimes cutting off two neighborhoods for hours. Emergency services and health care workers can’t get in, and those trapped inside can’t get out.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis, Mark Walker and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Dirty Socks and Rotting Bodies: What Russians Left Behind in the Trenches
articles.snippet: As Ukrainian troops inch forward in the counteroffensive, they are occupying positions abandoned by enemy troops. Says one: “It’s not very pleasant.”
articles.abstract: As Ukrainian troops inch forward in the counteroffensive, they are occupying positions abandoned by enemy troops. Says one: “It’s not very pleasant.”
articles.lead_paragraph: A bottle of syrup made from Siberian berries, legions of dirty socks and a military-issued tea bag stamped with “For Victory!”
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder

articles.headline: Trump Lawyers Seek Indefinite Postponement of Documents Trial
articles.snippet: The former president’s legal team argued in a court filing that no trial date should be set until all “substantive motions” in the case were resolved, setting up an early key decision by Judge Aileen M. Cannon.
articles.abstract: The former president’s legal team argued in a court filing that no trial date should be set until all “substantive motions” in the case were resolved, setting up an early key decision by Judge Aileen M. Cannon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump asked a federal judge on Monday night to indefinitely postpone his trial on charges of illegally retaining classified documents after he left office, saying that the proceeding should not begin until all “substantive motions” in the case had been presented and decided.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Judge Rejects F.T.C. Delay of $70 Billion Microsoft-Activision Deal
articles.snippet: Microsoft also said it was negotiating changes to the deal to satisfy objections made by a British regulator, which could allow it to complete its purchase of the video game giant as soon as this month.
articles.abstract: Microsoft also said it was negotiating changes to the deal to satisfy objections made by a British regulator, which could allow it to complete its purchase of the video game giant as soon as this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday ruled against the Federal Trade Commission’s attempt to delay Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard, setting the stage for the tech giant and the video game publisher to merge as soon as this month.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning, David McCabe and Karen Weise
